results.title: Petunia (K)
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Audio Visual Aids
results.brief_description: Petunia, the silly goose, is the self-appointed adviser to the barnyard animals. Masking her ignorance, she struts around with a book under her wing. However, when she interprets the word DANGER as “candies”, near tragedy results. Based on the book by Roger Duvoisin.

results.title: Pets and people: The story of Uncle Ben's in Australia
results.creator_credit: John Kenyon and Sapphire Films Melbourne
results.brief_description: Don’t let the titles fool you - this thinly disguised documentary has little to do with people and their pets. Rather it is a piece of shameless promotion of Uncle Ben’s pet food. At times the film also looks at Albury - Wodonga - however one comes to realise that such a focus is looked at only in terms of Uncle Ben’s community involvement. Once you locate the essence of the film, what you see that is really about is a decentralised industry, quality control and general propaganda.

results.title: Petronella
results.brief_description: An animated fairytale about a princess, who because she is an only child, must perform the traditionally princely duty pf rescuing a princess. Instead she rescues a prince.

results.title: Petroleum's progress
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott and Tom Fletcher
results.brief_description: Archival footage and commercials provide a history of oil and oil by-products, and of the creation of the petro-chemical industry. Man has developed a frightening dependence on oil. Not only do oil by-products keep him warm and mobile, they help to feed, clean, clothe and entertain him. The film makes the point that there is yet no substitute for oil.

results.title: Petroleum
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and A. Frank Bundy
results.brief_description: A detailed study of rotary drilling, including the preliminary surveying, the preparation of the site, the erection of the derrick, and the installation of the lengths of pipe; making an oil test the process of “bringing in the well”, transport of crude oil by pumping from well to storage tanks, and then by pipeline to the refinery at the coast, where it is refined into petrol and the numerous by-products of petroleum, for shipment overseas.

results.title: Petrochemicals
results.brief_description: This six part educational series deals with various aspects of the petrochemical industry and the part products play in everyday life. Parts of the program include: the building blocks, polymerisation reactions, polymers in use, solvents, detergents and industrial chemicals, agricultural chemicals, and chemistry in society.

results.title: Petit a Petit
results.brief_description:
Damoure and Lam leave Niger to travel to Paris in order to investigate the possibility of building a multi-storey building in Niamey. This is a pretext for Rouch and his interprets to cast a caustic look at French society and to indulge in largely improvised reversed ethnology. During their research trip in Paris, Damoure and Lam meet up with a young African prostitute, a bum and a young woman who is bored with her life to whom they extend an invitation to come and spend time in Niger with them.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Jean Rouch ; writer, Jean Rouch ; photography, Jean Rouch ; music, Enos Amelolon, Amicale de Niamey, Alan Helly.
Cast: Safi Faye, Damoure Zika, Lam Ibrahim Dia, Illo Gaoudel, Ariane Bruneton, Tallou Mouzourane.

results.title: Petersen
results.brief_description: Petersen is an electrician and former football star who yearns to be a teacher, so he attends university. But it’s the female professors, students, and all the women he comes in contact with who learn a thing or two from him. Stars Jack Thompson, Jacki Weaver and Wendy Hughes.

results.title: Peterborough Cathedral
results.brief_description: Scarred by invasion and fire, the Cathedral has passed through architectual periods og great interest. From the west door there is an unbroken vista to the alter and the lofty choir. In the 15th Century eastern chapel with its fine fan-vaulted roof, is the famous Monk’s stone.
